profiles:
Summary I am a software engineer, researcher and lecturer. Interested primarily in the development of intelligent software systems addressed to improve the quality of health care and reducing medical errors. 
 
I am currently a research software developer at the Stanford Center for Biomedical Informatics Research (BMIR) of Stanford University, which is worldwide recognized as one of the leading research centers in knowledge management and intelligent systems development.  
 
Research lines & interests: 
- Knowledge representation, sharing and reusing - Biomedical ontologies 
- Medical information systems 
- Semantic Web and Linked Data 
- Software engineering (Web applications) 
- Natural Language Processing Summary I am a software engineer, researcher and lecturer. Interested primarily in the development of intelligent software systems addressed to improve the quality of health care and reducing medical errors. 
 
I am currently a research software developer at the Stanford Center for Biomedical Informatics Research (BMIR) of Stanford University, which is worldwide recognized as one of the leading research centers in knowledge management and intelligent systems development.  
 
Research lines & interests: 
- Knowledge representation, sharing and reusing - Biomedical ontologies 
- Medical information systems 
- Semantic Web and Linked Data 
- Software engineering (Web applications) 
- Natural Language Processing I am a software engineer, researcher and lecturer. Interested primarily in the development of intelligent software systems addressed to improve the quality of health care and reducing medical errors. 
 
I am currently a research software developer at the Stanford Center for Biomedical Informatics Research (BMIR) of Stanford University, which is worldwide recognized as one of the leading research centers in knowledge management and intelligent systems development.

- Software engineering (Web applications) 
- Natural Language Processing I am a software engineer, researcher and lecturer. Interested primarily in the development of intelligent software systems addressed to improve the quality of health care and reducing medical errors. 
 
I am currently a research software developer at the Stanford Center for Biomedical Informatics Research (BMIR) of Stanford University, which is worldwide recognized as one of the leading research centers in knowledge management and intelligent systems development.  
 
Research lines & interests: 
- Knowledge representation, sharing and reusing - Biomedical ontologies 
- Medical information systems 
- Semantic Web and Linked Data 
- Software engineering (Web applications) 
- Natural Language Processing Experience Research Software Developer Stanford University April 2015  – Present (5 months) Stanford, California Visiting Scholar Stanford University October 2013  –  April 2015  (1 year 7 months) Stanford, California Software Engineer & Research Assistant Biomedical Foundation of CHUVI January 2011  –  December 2013  (3 years) Vigo Area, Spain Responsibilities: 
Design, development, evaluation and dissemination of an ontology based expert system for decision support at Cardiac Intensive Care Units.  
 
Accomplishments:  
- Development of a Java API to interact with Alaris drug infusion pumps.  
- Development of a Java API to interact with Philips IntelliVue monitors.  
- Development of an ontology-based expert system to provide the physician with a recommendation about the treatment that should be administered.  
- Evaluation of the system in the Intensive Care Unit of the Meixoeiro Hospital Center (Vigo, Spain).  
- Dissemination of the work in conferences, book chapters and international journals.  
 
Skills:  
- Excellent writing and speaking skills and ability to communicate with physicians 
- Ability to understand and learn medical concepts  
- Object-oriented design and design patterns  
- Knowledge about the protocols used by Carefusion-Alaris infusion pumps and Philips IntelliVue patient monitors  
- Technologies: Java, MySQL, XML, SWRL, RDF, OWL, APIs to manage serial and LAN communications 
 
A scientific paper describing the work that has been done is available at: http://www.hindawi.com/journals/cmmm/2013/650671/ Assistant Professor University of A Coruña September 2011  –  October 2013  (2 years 2 months) A Coruña Area, Spain Responsibilities: 
- Teaching courses, supervision of final degree projects, dissemination of research in journals, books and conferences, participation as a journal reviewer, participation in research projects funded by the Spanish government.  
 
Courses taught:  
- Systems Integration (Object-Oriented programming concepts, Design patterns, Front-end and Back-end development, .NET, Visual Studio, C#, Entity Framework, SQL Server, XHTML, XML, XSLT, CSS, AJAX). Degree: Master in Information Systems Engineering.  
- Semantic Web (RDF, SPARQL, DBPedia). Degree: Master in Information Systems Engineering. PhD student and Research Assistant University of A Coruña May 2006  –  December 2011  (5 years 8 months) A Coruña Research related to the field of biomedical ontology evaluation and recommendation. More details about the research achieved can be found at my personal website: www.marcosmartinezromero.com (see Publications section) Research Software Developer Stanford University April 2015  – Present (5 months) Stanford, California Research Software Developer Stanford University April 2015  – Present (5 months) Stanford, California Visiting Scholar Stanford University October 2013  –  April 2015  (1 year 7 months) Stanford, California Visiting Scholar Stanford University October 2013  –  April 2015  (1 year 7 months) Stanford, California Software Engineer & Research Assistant Biomedical Foundation of CHUVI January 2011  –  December 2013  (3 years) Vigo Area, Spain Responsibilities:

Summary I am a Software Engineer, specialized in Java application and API design. My prior master work focused on data analysis using Social Network Analysis and Statistics. I have a research-based experience in Knowledge-Base Representation, Domain Model and Databases. 
 
I have an open-source project called Semantika. The project promises a robust, high-performance RDB2RDF connector for constructing an intuitive query service over database system. The product is licensed under Apache License 2.0 and the source code is available via Github. 
 
Currently I'm joining the Protégé development team in Stanford University which I will involve in Protégé extension projects for biomedical purposes. I am a Software Engineer, specialized in Java application and API design. My prior master work focused on data analysis using Social Network Analysis and Statistics. I have a research-based experience in Knowledge-Base Representation, Domain Model and Databases. 
 
I have an open-source project called Semantika. The project promises a robust, high-performance RDB2RDF connector for constructing an intuitive query service over database system. The product is licensed under Apache License 2.0 and the source code is available via Github. 
 
Currently I'm joining the Protégé development team in Stanford University which I will involve in Protégé extension projects for biomedical purposes. Experience Research Software Developer Stanford University School of Medicine July 2015  – Present (2 months) Stanford, CA Execute all programming tasks, including programming, analyzing, designing, developing, implementing, modifying, and maintaining the current Protégé ontology-development environment. There will be some extensions for Protégé which include new features for the core Protégé system, to its Web version, WebProtégé and its customizations, such as iCAT. Some of the extensions will require the implementation of features to support large scale collaboration in the Protégé-based tools. 
 
As research software developer, l'm responsible for (1) designing, developing, documenting and testing the new features, (2) interacting closely with our collaborators, (3) providing technical support for users on the Protégé and iCAT mailing lists, (4) working with the other members of the Protégé team to integrate new features (e.g., migrating iCAT from Protégé OWL to the OWL API) in the Protégé platform. I pose solutions and develop software that demonstrates novel capabilities in response to research requirements. Founder Obidea Technology October 2013  – Present (1 year 11 months) Indonesia Founder of Obidea Technology. I am the author of Semantika software, a Java library for mapping relational data model to a domain model. The library demonstrates the most recent development in semantic web technology for data modelling and data integration. 
 
I made use of some open-source projects, such as OWL-API, Sesame, Jena, JDBC and Apache projects and applied several W3C standards, such as SPARQL, OWL, R2RML, RDF/RDFS, XML Schema Datatype. I released the software as open-source under Apache License 2.0. Data Analyst Open Data Lab Jakarta August 2014  –  July 2015  (1 year) Jakarta, Indonesia The Open Data Lab Jakarta is a project promoted by the World Wide Web Foundation to unlock the benefits of open data for Indonesia. The team is working closely with local and national government officials, practitioners and researchers to experiment the usefulness of open data in Indonesia. 
 
As a data analyst, I do work mostly on locating, cleaning, and analysing data from various sources (government, social media, private sector) as well as developing application and visualisation to public audience to demonstrate the potential value of open data. Other than that I help organise and conduct trainings on open data tools, technical concepts, including standards, formats, and infrastructure. Software Developer KRDB Centre (Free University of Bozen-Bolzano) October 2010  –  September 2013  (3 years) Bolzano, Italy Senior developer in Ontop project. I was responsible in writing and testing the software product. The development is part of a research in Ontology-based Data Access that gives a semantic layer to relational database system. 
 
In 2012, the team won a research grant and join a global EU project, called the Optique project (website: http://www.optique-project.eu). This project is financed by the European Commission Seventh Framework Program (FP7) with an estimated annual budget of €3.5 million. The project mainly focuses on data integration and Big Data in large industry. Web Developer Visioninfo Srl September 2009  –  February 2010  (6 months) Merano, Italy Web developer as an internship job. I worked for a hotel supplier company in which I developed websites for online publishing dan product catalog. Software Developer Pusilkom UI October 2006  –  July 2007  (10 months) Depok, Indonesia Software developer in the e-Passport project for the Indonesian Ministry of Foreign Affairs (or Deplu). I was responsible for developing a back-end prototype for reading/writing data into RFID tokens. Server Administrator Grid Computing Research Group July 2006  –  December 2006  (6 months) Depok, Indonesia I worked as a grid server administrator for the inGRID project. The project was sponsored by the Indonesian Higher Education Department to utilise the high-speed network among major universities in Indonesia. I worked in software installation and service provisioning. Summary I am a software engineer committed to quality and improving customer experience. I have worked in multiple organizations at all levels of abstraction, from assembly-level board bringup to Windows multitasking development in C++. Everywhere I've been, I have received commendations for my unfailing focus on the customer and meeting their needs. 
 
I am equally comfortable using straight procedural constructs in 'C' to building software from semantically complete OOA models that are automatically translated into code. I have helped to write state-machine-based, event-driven real-time architectures that relied on distributed object communication. I am fully versant with multiprocessing and multithreading, including various IPC mechanisms and tasking models. 
 
I enjoy working on development tasks throughout the complete process. I have written functional requirements specifications, solicited user feedback, designed entire applications from the ground up, and written verification tests for complex, real-time, embedded firmware medical devices. Many organizations live by their tools, and I've written critical toolsets for multiple organizations targeted at automating tasks such as code verification and requirement test coverage. 
 
I believe that because the software field is changing so rapidly, continuing education is an absolute must. To that end, I am constantly applying new technologies, reading and taking college courses to ensure that my skills and techniques are world class. I am currently focusing on graphics algorithms, programming, visualization, computer vision, and other graphic-related topics. I'm also interested in distributed systems and the networking field. 
 
I hope that these attributes are also important to your organization and that I can help you achieve your software goals. Specialties:C/C++, Python, Qt/PyQt, Linux, Systems Programming, Java, Executable Translatable UML, OOA/OOD, Multithreading, Sockets, TCP/IP, Multitasking and IPC Mechanisms, Embedded Systems, Hardware Interface, Medical Device Development, Requirements Analysis Summary I am a software engineer committed to quality and improving customer experience. Specialties:C/C++, Python, Qt/PyQt, Linux, Systems Programming, Java, Executable Translatable UML, OOA/OOD, Multithreading, Sockets, TCP/IP, Multitasking and IPC Mechanisms, Embedded Systems, Hardware Interface, Medical Device Development, Requirements Analysis Experience Sr. Software Engineer Consultant Personalis, Inc. February 2014  – Present (1 year 7 months) Menlo Park, CA I am working in a team that is developing an in-house, web-based tool for improving clinical interpretation of genetic variants. I am doing full-stack development, including a Python-based, Django controller interfaced to Apache running on a CentOS server, a MySQL backend, and JavaScript/jQuery/jQueryUI/DataTables front-end. My work covers the entire software design lifecycle (SDLC) from user interviews, requirements gathering, mockups, prototypes and, eventually, implementation. Musician Sonos Handbell Ensemble September 1995  – Present (20 years) I play, arrange, and assign for the ensemble. Sr. Software Engineer Silicon Valley Medical Instruments, Inc. June 2010  –  February 2014  (3 years 9 months) Fremont, CA I develop multi-process, real-time Qt-based GUI software that runs on Ubuntu Linux 12.04 for medical visualization. 
 
I'm currently responsible for implementing a real-time display of streaming ultrasound data using OpenGL and C++/Qt, an in-field system updater in PyQt using partimage, and the system initialization process. 
 
I am also developing the manufacturing process for generating our device's software. This involves low-level Linux work, including partition management, filesystem creation, GRUB2 configuration, and creation of live CDs to perform hands-off installation. 
 
My internal manufacturing tool project uses Qt, an off-the-shelf Tek oscilloscope, our proprietary ultrasound generation technology, and a test jig to implement a manufacturing test tool. This tool will automate processes relating to manufacturing our world-class IVUS catheter imaging core. It involves communicating with the scope via USB in Tek's control language from a Qt-based Linux application. This application will improve the workflow of our multiple manufacturing lines, saving time and money. Technologies include simple digital signal analysis, HTML report generation, and state-machines for controlled workflow. This project has been deployed to our remote manufacturing site. 
 
I am currently implementing a C++/Qt project on Windows 7 to perform automatic conversion of proprietary-format data into DICOM-compatible IVUS studies for manipulation by DICOM viewers and import into hospital PACS systems. This application involves both user interaction and background operation. The Qt State Machine framework drives much of its behavior. 
 
I have recently taken over a C- and asm-based embedded project using an Atmel ATxmega processor to precisely control a BLDC motor-controlled linear translation stage for IVUS investigations. I also accured another C/microcontroller-based project for precisely controlling the rotational velocity of the spinning ultrasound core inside our catheter sheath. Research Software Developer Stanford University February 2009  –  August 2010  (1 year 7 months) Member of Photon Control & Data Systems group, a cross-functional team that supports LCLS (Linac Coherent Light Source) experimenter/customers in delivering a high-quality, high-availability x-ray laser beam (FEL - Free-Electron Laser) that provides femtosecond-scale bursts. Responsible for motor control for the inaugural LCLS experiment, AMO (Atomic, Molecular, and Optical) experiment's base table alignment and diagnostic reporting via EPICS (Experimental Physics and Industrial Control System), a networked, distributed framework popular in high-energy physics installations. 
 
I currently contribute to all motion system controls, including designing the device database (like action data-flow diagrams), implementing machine protection safety systems, and creating customer and test GUIs. I also help debug motor drivers, detect system wiring issues, specify cabling, and install motion systems. 
 
I contributed a multi-threaded, C-based Python wrapper to allow scripts to interact directly with the control system. I wrote a native PyQt library and a QtDesigner plugin in Python so customers could create their own GUIs in QtDesigner. 
 
I work in a cross-functional team, collaborating with mechanical and electrical engineers, technicians, instrument scientists and experimenters. I give user training in how to use my GUI-based monitoring and control system and provide 24-hr. support during critical, must-work commissioning and science data-gathering periods. 
 
I transitioned over to the data acquisition team (DAQ) to work on their high-speed networking (10GbE) projects as well as developing a custom Linux kernel driver for a high-speed position encoder readout board. The encoder readout was used to determine the distance between two objects at the exact instant that a laser wavefront was fired into a chamber. The driver acted as a sensor and fed data into the overall DAQ network. 
 
The DAQ work was done on RHEL 5.4. Senior Executive VP of Begging The Dole October 2008  –  February 2009  (5 months) Analyzed personal economic conditions, navigated complex government interactions, successfully squeezed thousands of dollars out of stingy government regulators. Sr. Software Engineer St. Jude Medical November 2006  –  October 2008  (2 years) Sole software engineer in the Atrial Fibrillation (AF) division. Authored and responsible for maintenance of wxPython-based in-field firmware updater transferring image files across RS-232. 
 
Also contributed to maintenance of ARM7-based RF generator application for directing high-intensity ultrasound energy to ablate cardiac tissue and reduce the incidence of atrial fibrillation. Application was a bare-metal, OS-less design originally implemented by contract design firm. 
 
Initiated project to re-implement RF generator application with totally new hardware and software platform. The hardware reproduced the functionality of the previous device but used off-the-shelf components instead of custom FPGAs. Fitted an off-the-shelf UML (executable UML, xtUML) architecture developed by Andrew Mangogna for use on my platform. Applied Sr. Software Engineer St. Jude Medical January 2006  –  October 2006  (10 months) Embedded firmware development in 'C' in a team producing an implantable cardiac defibrillator. Implemented a state machine dispatcher, decision tree evaluator, and contributed to diagnosis and diagnostic functionality. Sr. Software Engineer St. Jude Medical October 2005  –  January 2006  (4 months) Worked in a team developing an xtUML model compiler. Sr. Software Engineer St. Jude Medical June 1997  –  October 2005  (8 years 5 months) Developed infrastructure and applications for an in-house, automated, real-time embedded firmware test platform. SQA Engineer Ventritex November 1995  –  June 1997  (1 year 8 months) Designed, wrote, and performed both manual and automated software tests for embedded firmware in implantable medical devices. Programmer/Analyst Allied Signal Aerospace May 1992  –  October 1995  (3 years 6 months) Developed system test applications for NASA groundstations as part of the Deep Space Network that tracked all space probes beyond earth orbit. Telemetry Analyst Bendix Field Engineering October 1990  –  October 1992  (2 years 1 month) Wrote applications to determine spacecraft and groundsystem efficiency based on downlink parameters (telemetry) for NASA's Deep Space Network (DSN). Completed CS6810 Artificial Intelligence (A). My final project used C++ and Qt to visualize a fuzzy-logic control system for a robot to perform a slalom - finding and going between pairs of goal posts. I also: 
 
* implemented simple DFS state-space search in Lisp for the "Cannibals and Missionaries" puzzle 
 
* used a genetic algorithm in Python to find a locally-optimal solution for a 20-city Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) 
 
* created a Connect-4 player in Lisp optimized via minimax combined with alpha-beta pruning to reduce the state space 
 
Completed an independent study project (A) for a CS graduate assistant to help her determine graduation status for CS majors. This lifecycle project involved a moderately sophisticated GUI using C++ and Qt under KDE and Windows with requirement gathering, interviews, mockups, implementation, installation, and support. See SourceForge.
